region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made some tweaks to the recipe according to the previous reviews and my own personal tastes. First of all, I tried to use lower fat ingredients when I could (Fat-free cream of mushroom, reduced fat cream cheese) 

I dredged the chicken in seasoned flour and heated a bit of oil and sautéed them for about 3-5 minute on each side, just to get a golden color and a little crispiness. Then I removed the chicken and prepared the sauce in the pan after de-glazing with chicken broth. I added just chicken broth instead of wine and increased it to about 2 1/2 cups because the sauce seemed really thick. (We personally don't like thick sauces and the "stick to your ribs" feeling). I added the chicken back and simmered for twenty minutes. It tasted great! 

Side note, the italian dressing mix smells and tastes a bit like the mix to make those pasta side salads so if you are a fan of those, you will love this meal.

userID:
3335477
Display Name:
Jackie
isPro:

13

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am very leary of trying new recipes when having guests, but this dish received such rave reviews that I prepared it for a small luncheon. It received rave reviews from every guest.  This is an easy and exceptionally good dish. As suggested by many others, I did make a few changes to the original recipe.

I used 4 boneless chicken breast cut into pieces, 1 plus 1/2 packets of Good Season Italian dressing mix, 1 cup plus a bit more  low salt chicken broth, 2 cans mushroom soup, 2 tubs cream cheese with chives, and  sliced fresh mushroooms.

 Soften the cream cheese, mix all ingredients, and cook on low in the crock pot for 5 hours. Serve over pasta.

This recipe lacks color. I added  chopped steamed brocolli just before serving and next time will consider adding thinly sliced red pepper to the crock.

I highly recommend this recipe!

Several cooks complained about the salty taste of the original recipe.  I am happy to have only used 1 1/2 packets of dressing as I think that the recipe would be too salty. I also used low salt chicken broth.

text:
I made this recipe as directed. Flavor wise- the sauce was a 5 star keeper. But.... I did have a few complaints from family and I both- 1- it looks bland- no color;2- not enough sauce;3- needs some veggies; 4- either chicken was behind done and tough or other pieces were not done at all (actually I can't really blame the recipe on this- this was probably user error) 
Anyway, I made it a second time, doubled the sauce and Placed everything in the crockpot. I added a package of sliced mushrooms. Cooked on low for 5 hours. I steamed broccoli (awesome with the cheese sauce)and added that and after serving it on plates, I cooked up some red pepper slices to through on top. Looked much better. :-)

text:
Wow! This was a huge hit! I thought I made more than enough for leftovers for lunch the next day, but there are barely two servings left! We are not huge fans of mushrooms, so we used cream of chicken soup, and I didn't have any white wine, so I used 1/4 cup of red wine and 1/4 cup of water. I tasted it before and after I added the wine/water mix, and it did make a difference. I used regular cream cheese and added my own dehydrated chives. I used gigantic frozen chicken breasts, and threw it all in a 9x13 baking dish and it still only took 1 hour to cook!
Thanks for the great recipe! My family has asked that this become a staple dish for dinner! I would love to try the crock pot version that another reviewer suggested, what an easy way to cook it!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall we were disappointed.  Followed the recipe to a T - made it in the crock pot, doubled the sauce to make sure there was enough.  I wonder how many people actually use Golden mushroom soup vs cream of mushroom?  Golden has a very distinct flavor, and I think lends itself more to beef dishes.  The sauce was very salty, and I love salt, I salt everything more than I should.  It's very rare that anything is too salty for me.  I had to add some half n half to temper the salt.  I used Good Seasons brand Italian dressing, so if you use that, either don't use it all or be sure to get low sodium soup!  The flavor of the sauce was very strong.  It did not need to be doubled.  When I saved the leftovers, I only added enough sauce to slightly color the pasta and it was better, although I still didn't care for the golden soup in this recipe.  If I were to make it again, I would use cream of mushroom soup and half of the dressing packet.

Next time I'm going to season & cut up the chicken prior to cooking and also try the crock pot method.
I only cooked 1/2lb of the spaghetti & it was plenty for my family of 4 and there was plenty of sauce for it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This wasn't my favorite dish that I've ever made from AllRecipes ... but in all honesty I'm not a huge fan of chicken and pasta dishes, I tried it because I was looking for something different to do with chicken. But I did not stick to the OPs directions, I veered off into my own little cooking world, so I won't downgrade the recipe for mistakes I may have made. And also, I see this sauce as an excellent base for other dishes to try: ham and peas with penne using cream of chicken soup...shrimp and scallops with asparagus using cream of celery soup...it's all good!

I couldn't find Golden mushroom so I used cream of mushroom (2 cans) and 2 T tomato paste. Combined that with 8 oz cream cheese, 1 T chives, 1 packet Italian dressing mix, 14 oz chicken broth. Heated through till smooth. In a large electric skillet I sauteed the cubed chicken with a little olive oil for about 5 minutes, then added onions and garlic, cook for another 5 minutes. Added a little white wine and cooked a little longer before adding the sauce, then cooked a bit longer while the pasta cooked. Thought the chicken would break down and become tender but it was rubbery. The flavor of the sauce was very good.

text:
This is a GREAT dish!  The only changes I made were:  Doubled the sauce (all except the salad dressing mix) and used fettuccine noodles.  I baked the chicken in the sauce, took the chicken out of the sauce after baking and sliced it into nice thin pieces.  I mixed the noodles & sauce together & put the sliced chicken on top to serve it.  It stayed in the oven on warm a few minutes while I got the rest of the meal together.  Looked awesome and tasted even better.  Planning to make it for an entire varsity boys swim team & they are gonna love it!  (Will be multiplying the sauce by 6 and noodles by 4!) Great company dish!

Easy and very flavorful. I used shredded, cooked chicken that I had cooked earlier and froze instead of the breasts. Mixed the chicken into the saucepan & let simmer for about 15 minutes - skipped the oven altogether. Just cooked the noodles & poured the chicken sauce over top. Oh & I didn't have any wine on hand, chicken stock worked fine. I will definately make this again.

text:
I followed the suggestions of other reviewers and doubled the sauce (but not Italian seasoning) since I like a lot of sauce on my pasta.  I cut the butter, and did this in the crock pot.  It was super easy, but a bit bland at first (which made me wish I had doubled all ingredients, including the Italian dressing packet - the salt content may just depend what brand you get!).  I did have to doctor it up quite a bit with some Italian seasoning, a bunch of garlic powder, pepper, etc. before serving.  Sprinkled fresh grated parmesan, parsley, and smoked paprika on top.  It ended up quite creamy and good!  In the end I had to alter the original recipe quite a bit (hence 4 and not 5 stars) until it was ready to serve, but knew I would need more sauce...

text:
this is a great recipe and it can be modified as to what you have on hand. I cut up 2 large boneless chichen breasts in large chunks.Used plain mushroom soup,fresh chives with the cream cheese that I had to finish up,dried italian spice mix from this site(no need to buy packaged).Added couple sprigs of fresh oregano as I still had some.Put in crock pot and cooked on low for 4 hours or so.I did follow the rest of recipe. When done added some sliced GREEN olives and fresh parsley cut up.Mixed with penne pasta(about 3 cups UNCOOKED) and we loved it.Husband said this is a keeper .THANKS!!!

text:
This was very very tasty!  I melted the butter in the microwave, them mixed in the soup, wine and dressing packet, and heated that up, then added the cream cheese in chunks and heated again until melted, and whisked smooth.  Poured over three chicken breasts, and baked for an hour as directed.  I would have given it five starts, but even with half the chicken, there was still not enough sauce to adequately coat the pasta.  Next time, I'll double the sauce and add freshly minced garlic too.  Also, I think it would be just fine with half the butter.  But overall, this was yummy yummy yummy.

text:
My family loved this!  UPDATE: I made this is the crock pot using 1 stick of butter, 8 oz. cream cheese, 1 cup white wine, 2 packets of dry Italian dressing mix, 2 cans of golden mushroom soup and one bag of frozen, skinless, boneless chicken breast. I cooked on high for about 4 hours, then removed the chicken and diced it. Whisked the sauce and returned the chicken and a box of cooked bow tie pasta. Delicious!

text:
My family loves this recipe.  We've made it even easier by turning it into a crockpot recipe.  I omit 2 T of butter, add baby bella mushrooms, and use cream of chicken/mushroom soup.  I cut chicken into strips, place in crockpot with mushrooms.  Cook sauce as directed and pour over chicken mushroom mixture.  Cook on low for 5-6 hours.  i've even used frozen breasts and they cook just fine.

country:

text:
Even though I changed this some, it still deserves 5 stars, for the idea atleast.  After I read alot of reviews, this is what I did and it was great.  The whole family said a definate keeper.  1/2 cup butter, 1 pkg dressing mix, 1 cup chicken broth, 1 can cr of mushroom, 1 can cr of chicken, 2 small cans mushrooms.  I warmed this up on the stove, then poured it over strips of chicken breasts in the crockpot.  Then stirred it together and cooked for about 5 hours. Then stirred in 1 8 oz pkg cr cheese and 1/4 c parsley while the bow-tie pasta was cooking.  It was kind of runny but made enough sauce for the pasta.  Very good and also the next day.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
This is one of my favorite recipes. I (like most others) have modified it a bit. I use 2 cans Golden COM soup, 1/2 c wine, 1/2 c chicken broth, almost the whole package(8oz) cream cheese, and a can (4oz) of mushrooms. This cuts way down on the saltiness and gives plenty of sauce for the noodles. I also grill the chicken and slice on top of the pasta...no oven required!

text:
It turned out great with some changes. I was making it just for my 2 parents and here are the ingredients I used: 2 skinless, boneless chicken breast  1/4 cup butter 20 g package dry Italian-style salad dressing mix just under 1/2 cup ginger ale + a bit of water 1 can cream of mushroom soup 4 ounces fat free herb & garlic cream cheese 1/2 pound penne pasta  They loved it and it was easy. I cut the chicken in strips before putting it in a baking dish, added broccoli and chopped red peppers to the sauce while in the pot, then poured it all over, covered with tin foil and baked for 55 minutes. Oh and before putting the chicken in the baking dish, I sprinked down garlic & italian seasoning. Put some pepper on the breasts too. Thanks for a fab recipe!!

I have now made this recipe twice and have thoroughly enjoyed it. text:
I followed this recipe exactly.  It was definitely too salty, and I really like salty food.  However, the flavor was great (why I gave it 4 stars).  When I make this again, I will definitely only use half of the dressing packet, or add some 1/2 and 1/2 to the sauce to tone it down- but that might take away from the creamy texture of the sauce.  Definitely DONT make this if you don't like salty food.  The chicken turned out really juicy.

text:
My family loves this one.  I've made some changes to make it tastier.

I melt the butter with the Italian seasoning mixed in, and put in baby bella mushrooms right away to simmer and soak in the flavor.  The original recipe doesn't make nearly enough sauce, so I add two cans of the soup and 8 oz of whipped cream cheese.  This makes the sauce much creamier and it covers all the chicken well plus leaves plenty of sauce to drape over the angel hair pasta.  One of my husband's favorites!

country:

text:
This is an easy recipe to make in the crock pot which is what I did.  I mixed all the ingredients except for the chicken in the crock pot and once everything was well mixed, I added the chicken which I diced up.  I added a little bit of onion.  I cooked it on low for about 4 hours.  I only used 2 chicken breasts but left the other ingredients at the original amounts to have more sauce which did work out well to put more sauce over the pasta or rice.  I would use the recipe "Italian dressing mix" from here instead of the packet from the store which is loaded with salt and fillers.  It will give it more punch and flavor.  I served it over rice to use up rice and chicken stock.  My husband said it had a lot of flavor and it was good.  We had broccoli along with it as well.  I think it'd be better over pasta as the recipe calls for.  Might add garlic next time.

This came out pretty good. I basically used LynnG's review as my recipe because I wanted to make it in my slow cooker. I used 1/2 C butter, 2 pkgs dry italian dressing, 1 C cooking white wine, 2 Cans mushroom soup, and 8 oz tub of cream cheese.I mixed them all in the slow cooker, coated the chicken with the mixture and cooked on low for about 8 hours. I served over fettucine noodles.  Next time I will probably use less soup because the sauce tasted a little too mushroomy for my taste.

This is great! I made mine on top of the stove, and served over cooked pasta. Per other reviews, I added (sauteed) mushrooms, and 3 or 4 chopped green onions. I had some grilled chicken tenders (boneless, skinless) that I need to use from my freezer, so I

Can't wait to eat it again tomorrow (we made a double batch) Also will try in the crock pot soon. Also used chicken stock instead of wine, and reduced fat cream cheese.

text:
Easy and yum! I used 1 lb. of chicken tenders that I cut into chunks and browned in a mix of butter and olive oil. Then I added the Italian dressing, plus a sprinkle of cayenne. Degalzed with the wine before adding 1 can of cream of mushroom with roasted garlic soup. I let this all simmer for awhile, adding more wine when the mixture got too thick. After about 20 minutes, I added the cream cheese, then a bit more wine, before mixing with the pasta. My boyfriend who prefers pasta with just butter and canned "parmesan" cheese loved this!

country:

text:
This is definitely a 5-star recipe in my opinion!  Plus, my family loved it...my 2-year-old daughter ate an adult-sized portion of it and loved every bite.  I made the sauce on the stove and then put 2 large chicken breasts in the crock pot and poured the sauce over them and cooked on low for about 4 1/2 hours.  I made a few minor changes: I used chicken broth (an entire 14.5 oz. can) instead of white wine, and used the whole 8 oz. block of cream cheese.  For some reason the cream cheese never did completely melt--it kind of curdled a little bit.  So after the chicken was done cooking, I poured the sauce into the blender and pureed it for a few seconds.  I used almost a whole 16 oz. box of penne, and that was great with it.  It served 3 adults and 2 kids with one good-sized portion leftover.  This will definitely be one of my regular recipes from now on.  So good!

text:
This recipe is divine and one I use as a company dish when I have guests.  I have a few modifications from the original.  I sauté the chicken in the butter until it’s golden on all sides; I use an entire eight ounce container of cream cheese with chives; and I use less pasta than the recipe calls for as I prefer more sauce.

text:
I have a toddler, so we cut the chicken up into small cubes beforehand, and use penne pasta instead of angel hair.  (It's easier to make it "finger food" that way.)  Like a previous poster, we double the wine and golden mushroom soup so it's not as salty.  I also use one 8 oz container of the whipped chive cream cheese.  The whipped version seems to melt better. My husband, my son and I all love this recipe.  It's our favorite off this site so far.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this dish for the second time tonight and it is definitely a keeper.  I do make it a little different to save some time.  Since it is just me and my husband, I butterfly 2 chicken breasts so they cook faster and season them with grill seasoning and saute them until they are done.  Then I remove them and let them cool a bit before I slice them up.  Then I make the sauce as directed in the pan the chicken was in and scrape up all the bits at the bottom with the grill seasonings.  I think the grill seasoning really gives it more depth in flavor.  I use chicken broth instead of wine, and I use cream of chicken soup instead of cream of mushroom (just personal preference) and I use dried chives because they are always on hand.  Then I stir the chicken back in a couple minutes before the pasta is done to heat them through.  I recommend using a more sturdy noodle than angel hair, thick spaghetti worked really well.  My husband had 3 bowls!!  And we have plenty of leftovers for lunch tomorrow.

text:
This was sooooooo good, tasted like something I would order at an Italian restaurant. With the cream of mushroom soup and cream cheese, the sauce was too thick for me...i added water 1/2c. at a time until it got to the consistency I wanted. Also, if you are going to double the sauce like I did, DO NOT double the Italian seasoning (IT IS VERRRRRY SALTY) in fact I would even cut down on the amount it calls for because before I started adding the water it was too salty and thick, then it got JUST RIGHT!! and oh soooooo yummy!! I added fresh mushrooms and red bell pepper. My husband thought it was delicious and he's not a pasta guy. Thanks!!

text:
Terrific meal!  I used plain cream cheese, added black olives, minced garlic, and mushrooms in addition to other ingredients. Softened cream cheese needs to be mixed well with melted butter or it tends to separate.  I put chicken breasts in crockpot, covered with sauce, and it only took 2-3 hours on HIGH.  The sauce was a little thin, so I may add more cream cheese next time.  We ate it with fettucini and steamed broccoli.  My husband and I both really enjoyed it.  Thanks for the recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/137090.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for something easy, fast and used ingredients that I already had in the kitchen. This fit the bill perfectly. I wasn't 100% sure that it was going to be all that great - but it was actually really yummy. I did make a few changes to fit my needs and preferences. I substituted a can of low sodium chicken broth for the wine, used 2 cans of golden mushrrom soup and used fat free plain cream cheese (I hate chives). I tossed everything in my crock pot and let the sauce start heating up some while I sliced the chicken breasts into strips. I let that all slow cook for about 5 hours. I cooked a lb of penne pasta (unsalted water), and added that to the crock pot and mixed it all up. I also steamed some chopped broccoli and heaped a serving on top of my pasta and mixed that into my pasta separately(since bf doesn't like veggies). It was a good dinner and leftovers (3 days worth of leftovers for us, lol) were good also. This is a good lazy day dinner - I'll use it again.

text:
This recipe was good but I know it could be better.  This was a fault of my own.  I wish I had listened to other reviewers who doubled the sauce.  I didn't double the sauce and should have.  It would have been more creamier (especially for leftovers).  Also, I didn't have a full packet of the italian seasoning (it was maybe 1/4 or 1/2 packet that I had left).  Because of that is the reason why I think it tasted a little on the bland side.  I'm sure if I had more of the italian seasoning, it would have tasted more flavorful.  I also cut the chicken up in cubes AFTER it was done in the oven, and that made it easier for my little girls to enjoy it.  I agree that angel hair pasta seems too 'thin' for this type of recipe, so I used fetuccine.  I do plan on making this again, using the proper amt. of italian seasonings AND doubling the sauce for sure. I really hope it will taste much better then.  :)

text:
This was very good! Although I was VERY leary of this recipe.  So I saw the huge reviews on this one and was kinda so-so about it.  And yah - the ingredients look odd, but it really is GOOD!  I would do as others state and add some fresh mushrooms (sliced) and let them cook while it all bakes.  I added a clove of garlic just because we love garlic.  No seasoning is neccessary.  The Italian Dressing mix is enough.  I didnt use a tub of cream cheese, I just cut off enough off an 8 oz. block and bought FRESH chives and it was better than the tub I would think.  Its not a cheap meal, but sooooo easy.  And so VERY FEW ingredients, its wonderful.  Not a 5* b/c I consider this a great base recipe.  Add other things to groove on the likes of your own family.  Yum!!!  My step-son and hubby said shrimp would taste great in this.  It would almost be like a Shrimp Alfredo they said.  Bake the sauce for a bit maybe, then chunk in shrimp at the last minute.  Oh Oh- use chicken AND shrimp.....SUPER YUM!!

I have not tried this yet (but gave it a 5 based on expectation and did not know how to respond to a member except through a rating-new to this), but was referred to it from the baked pork chops I recipe.  Quick note to Ms. Johnson about not being able to buy wine.  For the pork chop recipe above, that also called for wine, I used a white cooking wine gotten at the grocery store(no age requirement for that-lol).  I use it in anything that calls for wine.  It has been successful so far, so hopefully it would work for this recipe as well.  Good luck.  I can't wait to try this recipe!

text:
Very good stuff!  The first time I made this, I followed the recipe.  The next time, however, I made some changes.  I used egg noodles instead of the pasta, which was too sticky.  Rice would be good too, but never again would I use pasta with this sauce which turned out like goo.  I used my slow-cooker and doubled the sauce and used lots and lots of chicken ... enough leftovers for days, which warmed up well and kept me out of the kitchen.  Don't bother buying cream cheese with chives.  Just use regular cream cheese and add some chives.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I would give this recipe 3 stars but am giving it 4 because I think with a few adjustments this could be very good.  I liked the flavor of the sauce but it turned out a little thick, especially after it sat for a few minutes.  The chicken was kind of dry as well.  I will try it again cooking it for about 35 minutes at 350 which should remedy the dryness.  To thin out the sauce I would add a little more white wine and/or reduce the cream cheese to 3 oz.  I don't think I'll put the whole package of Italian dressing in either, it was a little too salty for my taste (and I like things salty!). UPDATE - made this again with these changes: used only 3 oz cream cheese, added 1/3 cup chicken broth so the sauce wasn't so thick, reduced the butter to 2 Tbsp and only added 1 tsp of the italian dressing mix.  Turned out very well, easy and tasty dish.

text:
This was so yummy.  Instead of breasts, I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs, cubed and browned them until cooked.  I sauteed them with sliced mushrooms as well.  Then when I finished the sauce, I added the chicken and mushrooms back into the pan and just simmmerd everything while the pasta cooked.  I'm not fond of angel hair, so I used fusili instead. I'm glad I did, because the pasta caught all that delicious sauce.

text:
We really loved this!  Because I read alot of reviews about the saltiness I used unsalted butter, 1/2 of the italian dressing mix, and instead of using wine I used 3/4 C of low sodium chicken broth.  I also sauteed some red peppers, garlic, scallions, and mushrooms and added them to the sauce before pouring over the chicken.  I also doubled the soup and cream cheese to make more sauce.  Sooo good!  I would season the chicken before puring the sauce on top too!  Add whatever spices and veggies you like and you will really enjoy this one!

text:
I loved this, but took tips from reviews.  I used 0.6 oz Good Seasons italian dressing mix, 1/2 c. butter, 3/4 c. low sodium chicken broth, 2 cans of Golden mushroom soup, and 8 oz. cream cheese with chives and onions.  I sprinkled paprika on chicken  before adding sauce, cut chicken into strips, and added tabasco and chopped green onion.  Excellent with your favorite angel hair.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After extensive experimenting, I have finally found a way around the saltiness. Instead of an envelope of dressing mix, I used the Italian Dressing Mix recipe found on this site, adding as much or as little as I wanted. I used unsalted butter, and good quality Marsala wine instead of white wine. Avoid using cooking wines, as they only add to the saltiness. (If it's not good enough to drink, don't use it.) I also added some half and half, as that also helps tone down the salt, and I always let it simmer, as I don't use the oven for this recipe. If it's still too salty, use some Italian seasoning instead of dressing mix. The sauce will turn out much better this way. I made the sauce by itself, and served it with thin spaghetti and Garlic Chicken from this site. Yum!

userID:
316018
Display Name:
MI Mommy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy AND delicious!  I was very skeptical that the raw chicken would cook in an hour at that temp under the sauce, but it did and it was FANTASTIC!  I used 5 or 6 chicken breasts (boneless) was sure to season both sides of the chicken (seasoned salt, garlic powder, pepper, paprika, minced onion), substituted chicken broth for the wine, used cream of chicken/mushroom soup (because that is what I had on hand) and I put a couple cans of mushrooms on top of the chicken before the sauce.  We tried it on top of whole wheat angel hair pasta (which tasted the same as the white pasta). Oh, I also used fat free cream cheese, smart balance light butter and fat free italian dressing powder.  I coudn't believe how creamy and delicious it was.  If you like alfredo type sauce, try this for a reduced fat/calorie alternative.  I suppose you could add some cheese to the sauce, but it was just right for us as is.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This is one of our favorites. I tend to double the sauce, but less than double the italian seasoning. If using wine, be sure to use a dry white...once I used a sweeter white, and it really threw the taste off. Also, instead of chicken breasts, I use ground chicken. The ground chicken seems to mix in better with the sauce, and it makes it easy to cook all in one pan on the stovetop.

country:
None
text:
Like other reviewers, I found this to be salty. I doubled the sauce and used 3 pounds of chicken. Some people thought the sauce was not enough. Maybe because they used 6 breasts, and not 6 breast halves like the author suggests(that would be 3 breasts). The sauce was enough for me. I will make it again, but next time, only one teaspoon of butter, and use regular cheese cream and add dried onions and chives to it, and maybe 3/4 of the packet. I think this will cut back on the salt. Be careful not to overcook the pasta, it cooks rather quickly (5 minutes is good).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an unusual one, but when all was said and done, it was really good.  Be sure all ingredients for the sauce are blended together.  It took about 15 minutes of periodic stirring to incorporate the flavors while on the stove (if you're like me, you'll notice the initial strong/over powering wine flavor, that goes away once the sauce is cooked down).  The only draw back (and reason behind the 4-star rating) is the amount of oil the cheese and Italian dressing mix produces.  Pools of orange colored oil formed while cooking in the oven.  Luckily, I had already planned to refrigerate the dish and served it the next day.  So, when it came out of the fridge, I was able to easily scrape off the excess oil.  Despite that, I would make this recipe again.

Fantastic!  This was one of the best-tasting chicken pasta recipes I've ever made.  It is so easy, and my whole family loved it - especially the kids! text:
This is really simple and yummy. I've made it several times and have discovered that I like it better if I use only half of the dressing packet (less salty). Also, if I'm in a hurry, I simply put the chicken breasts into the saucepan with the sauce and cook them on the stovetop in just a few minutes (as opposed to an hour in the oven). You sacrifice a bit of tenderness this way, but it's a fine shortcut. Still delicious.

I made this on the stovetop. I sauteed chicken tenderloins in olive oil, made the sauce and allowed it to simmer while I boiled the noodles. Then I tossed it all together.

Display Name:
CHINDERS

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6606055.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was quite good, but I did modify it a little.  Instead of raw chicken, I used a roasted deli chicken that I had frozen in pieces - just poured the sauce over frozen pieces and baked.  Came out very tender!  Now, I didn't use the 1/4 cup of butter, because I figured that the sauce was rich enough with the cream cheese.  Perhaps it tastes even better with butter, (I don't know!), but it is very good even without.  I used a whole cup of wine, and baked it with a foil cover so that I would not lose all the sauce as some people mentioned happens. I would probably uncover it for the last 15 minutes or so, just to get some browning action next time.
 I didn't have cream cheese with chives, but I had some Marscapone so I used that and added some green onions chopped up.  I think that it would go equally well over rice as pasta and will make this again, as my husband liked it very much.

text:
This is a terrific chicken dish!  I often take this dish to new moms, and it is very welcome.  I cut down the butter to 1/8 cup, use the reduced-fat cream cheese and fresh chopped chives, and use only 3/4 of the dressing mix.  These steps make it lower in fat and less salty.  Delicious!

text:
This dish was amazing.  I am a teenager who made this for my family and they thought it tasted great.  It was very simple to make, and although it takes some waiting while it cooks in the over, it is definately worth the wait. A suggestion is adding regular italian dressing instead of the powder-it tates the same, and it's more likely you'll have it around the house.  Also, use fresh chives and regular cream cheese-it tastes great!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish is WAAAYYYYY TOO salty.  I was really disappointed in this meal after reading so many favorable reviews, and I agree with all of those who warned against its saltiness. Taking the advice of some of the earlier reviews, I doubled the sauce recipe and added some fresh sliced mushrooms, but even using only one package of the salad dressing for the doubled recipe, and all low sodium or "lite" products, the sauce was still WAAAYYYY TOO salty. The chicken does come out tender and moist, and the sauce has a pleasant buttery wine taste, if you can get by the intense salty flavor.  I couldn't.  Not a good dish to make if you are watching your blood pressure.  I would neither make this again, nor recommend it to anyone.

Don't worry if when you first cook your sauce, you think it smells and tastes horrible.  I did, but once it had baked for an hour with the chicken, the wine flavor had mellowed and it was very good.  The chicken was moist and tender.  Be careful that you don't overcook your angel hair pasta, (it gets very mushy if you do). i made this for a murder mystery dinner party and everyone seemed to like it.

I sliced the chicken into strips, dipped it into a seasoned flour mixture and browned
it.  I added mushrooms, onions and celery to the pan
and sauteed them.  I poured the sauce over
the chicken mixture then baked it 35 minutes.  I also had trouble
finding the cream cheese with chives so I used cream cheese with chives and onion.  Tasted great!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A couple more ideas for using this recipe that I've tried.  One is that with leftover chicken, I chop it up and put it in the gravy and we put that over the noodles.  I have also taken chicken strips, dredged them in a seasoned flour mixture, then using the butter from the sauce, I've browned the strips. I then add the rest of the sauce ingredients (usually doubled).  This has been a good way to serve it for company - stretches the chicken without losing any of the yummy flavor.  I've also added a cup of chicken broth to the sauce to cut down on the richness.  I'm glad everyone likes it so well.  Marian

I'll most likely make this again.  Only thing is, I used chives and onion cream cheese because I couldn't find chives only cream cheese. I dunno if others have run into the same problem.

Pretty good! I made a few changes based on our family's tastes: 
-I used spaghetti instead of angel hair,
-I made only 3/4 lb of pasta but only used about 1/2 lb (we like our pasta saucy), 
-I cut up the chicken breasts into chunks,
-When it was done baking, I removed the chicken, out the sauce in a skillet and sprinkled 2 tbsp of flour and cooked until thickened.

region:

country:
None
text:
I substituted heavy whipping cream and fresh chives, since I didn’t have any cream cheese. The chicken breasts I’d bought were unexpectedly huge - each was significantly bigger & as wide as my fist. I only cooked one; so, I ended up doubling the ingredients for the sauce. The sauce wasn’t thick/heavy, since I used heavy cream. But, given that angel hair pasta is a more delicate pasta, I prefer a lighter sauce.

The first one was undoubtedly better than the 2nd - where I used the recipe’s portions. I did my usual herb and butter pasta; so, that likely enhanced the flavor. 

I had some doubts about the sauce after I’d mixed and tasted it  But, I took a leap of faith. Everyone loved it; so, I’ll definitely use this recipe in the future.

text:
Made exactly as recipe directed: delicious! If you're looking for an easy, go-to recipe, this is it. The richness of the sauce makes it seem like it took hours. My parents and in-laws love it when I make this...I get requests for it frequently. Since I have small kids, I think I will occasionally use the penne or rigatoni noodles to keep down the messiness. I have also cooked this in the slow cooker with great results. This is one you could easily add veggies, like mushrooms, or tweak it with a different flavor, like parmesan cheese, for a nice change. A keeper for sure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is very simple to make and the sauce is very delicious.  I followed this recipe and made substitutions with the sauce: I used 1 packet of seasoning, 1 can of golden mushroom soup, 1/2 cup sauvingon blanc wine,  doubled the butter (used 1 stick), added 1 Tbsp garlic, added 1 can chicken broth, and used entire brick of cream cheese.  The Golden Mushroom soup and wine were what made the flavor so amazing (in my opinion).   I lightly sauteed my chicken first in butter and olive oil with salt/pepper, then finished in oven baking.  Added sauce over angel hair pasta and finished chicken.  This one is a keeper!

userID:
2526519
Display Name:
Heidi

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made it many times as is.  It is 5 star.

Over time because my health needs have changed and I need to add more vegetables to my diet, I've added the following (all saute'd prior to adding to the sauce) - 1 8-ounce container of sliced mushrooms, 1/2 a head of small green cabbage, 1 small head of broccoli chopped up, and the full 0.75 ounce container of chives chopped.  I also add 1 cup of cream to the sauce to cut the saltiness.

I make the sauce first (without adding the mushrooms), put the sauce and frozen chicken breasts into my Instapot with a 1/2 cup of chicken broth.  It takes about 10 minutes on high pressure with a natural release.  You need to make sure the chicken has sauce beneath it in the Instapot so that the chicken doesn't burn.  If the chicken isn't cooked thru, put it back into the Instapot and add 3 minutes.  Then I shred the chicken in my KitchenAid mixer with the bread paddle.  Sauce and shredded chicken then get added to the cabbage, mushroom,  and broccoli mixture I saute'd.
Review:
Rating:
5

Made this a couple times. Didn’t like how the chicken breasts looked so pale after putting it into the oven so my second time making it I grilled the chicken on the outside and cut into bite sized pieces and mixed into the pasta. I used a rotini noodle and it grabbed up the sauce nicely and made a nice casserole style dish. Definitely going to make this again maybe as it is in the recipe but browning the breasts first so it looks a little nicer when serving.

One of my very favorite, quick and easy chicken dishes. I always read reviews before I make a recipe. I made this one as written (ingredient wise). I think it's perfect just the way it is. You need to be sure you're using the correct cream cheese here, that's what sets it apart. I read a review of someone using regular cream cheese which would give the dish a different taste all together. I enjoy serving this over pasta or mashed potatoes. Perfect!

text:
I have made this a few times. It's very easy and impressive. I double everything except the pasta and reduce the chicken to 3 or 4 breasts, each cut in half.  I add minced garlic to the butter and before I pour the sauce over the chicken, I add 8 ounces of sliced baby bella mushrooms, which cook in the oven in the sauce.  I have made it both with chicken broth and with white cooking wine.  The sauce tastes so much better with the wine and I'm a non-drinker!

text:
This was deeeeelicious. I was missing a couple of ingredients so I substituted canned mushrooms mixed with cream of chicken soup instead of the condensed mushroom soup. I also didn't have dry Italian salad dressing mix so I made my own with garlic powder, onion powder, salt, pepper, basil, oregano, parsley & celery salt. I covered with foil paper during baking so it would be juicer to make sure there was enough sauce for the pasta. It was just right. A definite keeper. I'm eager to try it in the slow cooker.

text:
Love this recipe, BUT I made this all on the stove— Semi-cooked the chicken first with butter then removed the chicken and made the sauce in the same pan. Used chicken broth instead of wine and used cream of mushroom only because I couldn’t find golden mushroom soup. I added the chicken back into the pan with the boiling sauce to soak in the flavor from the sauce. Super easy, quick, and delicious! Next time, before I add the ingredients for the sauce in the pan, I’ll sauté garlic and chopped onion to give it a much better flavor.

text:
I chg'd the measurements to 4 servings and then used the basics of this recipe in the crock pot with a pork loin roast.  It was amazing!  I cooked (from frozen) the pork loin in the golden mushroom soup w/ 1 cup water until it was at about 135 degrees.  I prepared the remaining ingredients for the sauce per recipe instructions and added it to the soup already in the crockpot.  I let the pork cook until it was 170 degrees.  I placed pork slices atop the angel hair pasta and poured sauce over top.  My 16 yr old son gave it a thumbs up. Will definitely make this one again.

text:
My 13 yr old gave this a 10 and my other 2 gave it a 7. I gave it a 7.5. It was very good but not outstanding.  I only had a smaller amount of chicken for the 4 of us. (1lb 8oz) so for the last 15 minutes I added in some cold cooked cut up lefterover chicken. It made the sauce better.  For the sauce I first fried some onion and garlic with the butter.  Then I added plain whipped cream cheese with the green part of a green onion which is like chives.  One can of soup and a tad more of the wine. It was great! Since I didn't have as much chicken I think I should have cut down on the cooking time. It was still moist but I hate over cooked chicken.  Over all a great meal and all 3 boys ate it which is always a plus.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I improvised to save some time and a trip to the grocery store but I don't feel it sacrificed taste in any way. I used a rotisserie chicken cut into pieces and a can of cream of chicken instead of mushroom and added the chicken after the sauce was prepared. This completely eliminated the oven portion. Also substituted for the Italian seasoning packet by following another Allrecipes suggestion using a .7 oz equivalent.  For those reviews that said it didn't have flavor, this may solve for that.  I also didn't use the chives (simply forgot) and didn't miss it. Toss in some frozen broccoli and meal in under 30 min. My son loved it. Would absolutely make again.

text:
Delicious and easy. Important to get GOLDEN mushroom soup -- I was about to grab cream of mushroom at the store and the flavor would've been much less interesting. Didn't use chive cream cheese, just used normal. Try to get the cream cheese to room temperature before stirring into the sauce. Added some heavy cream to stretch the sauce further; chicken broth would work too. 1lb of pasta is sort of overkill but nice for leftovers.

text:
Very good and easy to prepare but leans slightly towards the salty side (however I don't like salt so that's probably just my opinion).  I made this as is as should you,  except I used the whipped cream cheese and chive in a tub - (be sure to measure only 4oz tho!).  I would absolutely NOT substitute the wine. I think that is what made the dish special and got rid of the canned soup taste.  Adding  more canned soup like chicken broth just sounds way to salty and bland.    I do see this being more of serving to company  dish then just preparing it for weeknight supper so I will make it again next time I entertain.

text:
Like many here before me...I used 8 oz cream cheese, 1 cup white wine,  2 cans golden mushroom soup, a pkg of sliced mushrooms.  Also, sauteed 1 onion & 2 pieces of garlic in the butter.  Added the mushrooms. Deglazed w/ wine, then added cream cheese & juice  of one lemon.  Cooked only using cooktop...saw no advantage to baking.  Served over angel hair pasta.  Considering how easy this is...it deserves 4 stars just for ease of cooking.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not a cook, I bake. So when I venture into making meals it's a risky business. But this recipe intrigued me so I gave it a try. I really liked it but then I like anything that's cooked and not nuked from a box. I thought at first the sauce was way too salty but in the end, it was just right. I attribute this to the salad dressing mix - I don't usually use that stuff so didn't know what to expect. It's an easy way to add spices. My store didn't have golden cream of mushroom soup so I used Cream of Mushroom and Chicken. I also added 1/2 pound of sliced mushrooms. It seemed like a good idea. I didn't use the cream cheese with chives because I don't like onions or chives. I just used plain cream cheese. Oh, and I used 4 chicken breast halves instead of 6 - mine were really thick and rather than thaw out another package, I went with the 4. It turned out pretty darn good. It made a lot though so I'm going to freeze some of it to enjoy later. I really enjoyed the excuse of opening a bottle of wine for this recipe. In fact, I'm still enjoying it.

The flavors worked really well together; the only critique I have is that it was way too salty - probably because of all the processed food ingredients.

text:
This was a very good recipe. I did make some changes. My husband is on a low sodium diet so instead of using the package of Italian salad dressing mix I just sprinkled Mrs. Dash garlic and herb seasoning on the chicken breasts. I also used heart healthy cream of mushroom soup instead of the golden mushroom. I added a 7 ounce can of no salt added sliced mushrooms drained and about 8 ounces of cream cheese. I used 1/4 cup white wine and 1/4 cup sherry. The flavor was very rich and delicious. I served over linguine because that's what I had. I definitely will keep this in my rotation of chicken meals.

text:
I made this last night for dinner and did make some changes based on the reviews. I sauteed garlic with the butter and then added the wine to let it cook down a bit. I used one pkg of country herb dressing, two cans of soup and one small tub (8oz) of the chive and onion cream cheese. All things considered it was tasty but was still very salty. I added about a 1/4 tsp of sugar to try and cut the saltyness (is that the right spelling? lol) and it helped a bit but not much. Overall very good but next time I will use low sodium everything and see if that helps.

text:
Between the soup and the spice packet this recipe is way too salty. The consistency is also more goo than sauce.  I doubled the cream cheese and added 1 cup heavy cream to cut the saltiness and thin out the consistency. Even with these modifications it was still salty. If you are going to make this start with HALF the spice packet (or use a low sodium one) and then add more to taste.

text:
Pretty good, made some changes: melted the butter in a big wok, added 4 cloves garlic, then added strips of chicken breast with some black pepper, red pepper flakes, and a touch of italian seasoning.  Then I added the can of mushroom soup, cream cheese, and one cup of chicken broth. Also added some fresh lemon juice and zest of half a lemon. Stuck this all in the oven on 325.  While the sauce/chicken was in the oven I boiled some rotini along with frozen veggies (broccoli, carrot and cauliflower--california mix). Drained the veggies and pasta, and tossed the chicken and sauce with the pasta/veggies.

My family said this recipe is their new favorite! I sautéd some onions and spinach in the butter and then used 1 can cream of chicken and one can cream of mushroom. I also used 8 Oz of cream cheese. It was amazing. I broiled the chicken on the side with lemon pepper seasoning since my youngest doesn't like chicken.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked this chicken recipe. I absolutely cannot stand cream of mushroom soup so i used cream of chicken instead but made no other substitutions. My chicken was way overcooked at one hour of cooking. I recommend that you check your chicken at about 40-45 min. I did that the second time i made this and checked with a instant read therm. You really need to do this or you may end up with dry, chewy chicken. The sauce is really delicious and i have served this over rice also and very good that way too. A keeper recipe. Just don't overcook the chicken.

text:
OMG, this tasted like a dish from a nice Italian Restaurant. I did do some things differently. I sauteed fresh mushrooms, Shrimp, onion and garlic in butter then put them in the baking dish and made the sauce. Used two cans of Golden Mushroom soup, and 8 oz of the cheese, half plain and half chives and onion. Used a  cup of wine. Do NOT substitute for chicken broth, as this did make it .I covered it in foil for the first 40 minutes. I also put some fresh steamed Broccoli on top. Served with some baked Baguette bread. It was  fabulous! I think the shrimp made it awesome!

text:
I made the sauce as written, but only had 3 chicken breasts.  I cut them into strips so I could reduce the cooking time down to 40 minutes to appease a hungry 2 year old.  lol.  There were a few reviews that said it was too salty, but I did not think so.  I had white cooking wine that I used.  I'm sure it would taste even better with a higher quality wine.  But overall it was good, and even my grandson ate it...he's 2 and extremely picky.  It isn't as exciting as I thought it would be, but definitely better than I expected.  I also did not think it was bland as one review stated.  The chicken by itself is, but short of injecting flavor into the breasts, you will have that.  The sauce is great as it is in my opinion.

I love the taste of this recipe, but I did have to alter it. I use 8oz of cream cheese instead of just 4. I also use 2 cans of soup. One cream of mushroom and one cream of chicken. I also double the wine, but still only use one packet of Italian dressing. I add my own seasonings to it as well. (Wild Tree Garlic Galore) Cover when cooking and it creates enough sauce to properly coat the noodles that you'll serve it with.

country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe! It tastes like pasta roni but the GOOD KIND! Not processed that you could only take two bites out of. 

Reading the reviews and from watching the video, it looked like there wasn't enough sauce. Since I was only using 3 breasts I kept the original sauce measurements so that it would double itself.

The additions I made which tasted absolutely fantastic was sautéing a little sweet onion, fresh mushroom and 1 minced garlic. I then put that mixture as a bed before laying the chicken (I didn't mix it into the sauce because I didn't want to alter the taste). When I made the actual sauce mixture I also added aditional 2 garlic cloves to that. 

Besides that I think it was fantastic and will make it again!

text:
I love this dish! It's good as is, but of course, I fiddled around with it based on reviews/my own taste. 

I always use chicken broth instead of white wine. I made it with the wine once and just didn't like it as much. That's just me.

What I do now is double the sauce and throw it in the slow cooker. I also add a bag of frozen broccoli. SO GOOD.  

Chicken in the bottom of slow cooker, pour half the sauce on top, then pour in bag of broccoli, then top with the remaining sauce and cook on low for about 8 hours. Heavenly!

text:
Made as is = 4, it tasted good but seemed to need something. I made it with a side of corn on the cob and pan seared green beans. Now going back and reading other reviews I can see potential to get this recipe to a 5. I ended up cutting my chicken into strips for my leftovers to give the chicken more flavor. I like the idea of maybe using cream of chicken instead and next time adding broccoli but not all my kids like green beans so they did eat them this way. I also have to say that all 3 kids loved and devoured this dish. My hubby and I both thought it needed something, if only seasoning the chicken first and pan searing. Deffinetly a keeper!!

Display Name:
Karen Martin

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/190.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was really happy with this recipe. I followed the recipe this first time and it turned out well. I think the 60 minute cook time may be high for chicken breasts. Mine were a little dry. Since you are pouring the sauce over raw chicken, though, it may be necessary to get the sauce hot enough to kill the cooties. The recipe did not specify covered or uncovered so I opted for uncovered. I used some leftover champagne that I had frozen for the wine and it was a great flavor. Pros:  good sauce, I had plenty of sauce, chicken was tasty, prep was minimal. Cons:  lots of processed ingredients, chicken a tiny bit overcooked, long cook time. I think next time I will try cutting up the chicken into bite sized pieces and use the skillet preparation method and see if the chicken stays juicier, but may lose some flavor in the chicken if I don't cook as long. Plus more time standing over the stove instead of letting it cook itself in the oven. I think I will also add a touch of cream to maybe cut a tiny bit of the "condensed soup" texture. A big batch of sautéed fresh mushrooms would also freshen this up a bit.  Thanks for the recipe!

Very easy to make and reheats well for lunch the next day!  This was my first time trying this recipe, and will make again.  The wine "taste" did not completely cook away, so will substitute with homemade chicken stock or a half stock/half wine blend next time for my husband's benefit.  My 5 year old has the typical picky eater visual abhorrence of mushrooms so I poured the soup into a bowl to pick out the few mushrooms pieces before adding to the sauce, worked well and she gobbled it up.  Served with some shaved Parmesan cheese on top and some steamed green beans on the side!

text:
I followed this recipe exactly as written except I only used 2 chicken breasts and 2 portions of pasta because there were only 2 of us. I kept the sauce ingredients the same because I didn't want to have a partial can of soup left over and thought I could use the leftover sauce for something else. Only thing is, there was no leftover sauce. I don't think there would be enough sauce for 6 chicken breasts. The sauce was just OK tasting. It was very salty. I have looked at this recipe in the past but didn't make it because it didn't sound very healthy to me. Don't get me wrong - I have no problem eating something baked in cream cheese as long as it is worth it. Unfortunately, this was not worth it. I won't make again. I would've given less stars but the recipe was easy and the chicken was very moist.

text:
I always read the reviews before making a recipe. Many reviews of this pasta suggested doubling the sauce. I did this, assuming they meant double ALL ingredients in the sauce. Make sure you do not double the Italian Seasoning packet!! The flavor of this dish was so good, just way too much seasoning. The next time I make this, I will double the sauce, except use only ONE Italian Seasoning packet. I also used fresh chives, and topped with chopped broccoli. I made sure to slice the chicken in thin strips, and baked for 50 instead of 60 minutes. Can't wait to make it again.

text:
Just made this tonight. Very tasty! You definitely should double the sauce. I cut the chicken into strips, used 1 can golden mushroom and 1 can cream of chicken soup. Added 2 pkg of Italian dressing mix, i small can of mushrooms and used a $10.00 bottle of chardonay for the 1 c. of wine. I did add about 1/2 c. milk to the sauce as it was pretty thick. As the sauce sits, it will thicken up a bit anyway. Baked for 1 hr and 15 min. Very tasty and will definitely make again.

text:
This was really good and super easy (and cheap, always nice)!  I added some mushrooms and substituted chicken broth for the wine.  I cut the chicken up in pieces and browned in some olive oil and Italian seasoning, then tossed it in the skillet with the sauce.  I didn't bake it in the oven, just let it simmer for a while on the stove to save time.  I thinned the sauce down with a little cream before serving over whole-wheat thin spaghetti.  My husband and I both decided this was a keeper!

userID:
3881088
Display Name:
Pandora Spocks
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband gave this a 5 which is rare. I did have to make a few substitutions. I used 2 pounds chicken breast tenders cut into one inch pieces with kitchen shears, 1 stick butter, 1 package Lipton Savory Herb and Garlic dry soup mix, 1 cup white cooking wine (I know, gross right? But I didn't have any of the good stuff - came out great anyway), 1 can cream of mushroom soup, 1 can golden mushroom soup and 1 8oz. block of softened cream cheese with a sprinkling of dried chives. I also sauteed 5 oz. fresh sliced mushrooms and one small chopped sweet onion in 2 tbsp of the butter and 1 tbs olive oil before adding the chicken which I lightly browned on one side before adding all the rest of the ingredients. To lessen the dirty dishes, I cooked it all in a large covered skillet on the stove. I used a full pound of farfalle which I boiled separately while the chicken mixture was simmering and tossed the al dente pasta with the sauce in the skillet before serving. The chicken was cooked perfectly and the sauce was the perfect consistency. I will try this again when I actually have 2 cans of golden mushroom and the dry Italian dressing mix so I can taste the original as well. But with the minor substitutions we made and the doubling of the sauce ingredients, this provided 6 dinner size servings and was really really good. Thanks!

text:
This was absolutely delicious!  I didn't have Golden Mushroom soup so I used regular and added about 2 tablespoons Lipton Onion soup mix.  Didn't have cream cheese with chives so I used 8 oz regular cream cheese.  I don't eat pasta, but served this with English peas.  OMG, the gravy over the peas is like having creamed peas!  I melted the butter in the microwave then stirred in the other ingredients.  I cubed the cream cheese into the hot mixture and stirred until melted.  I cooked this in the crockpot for about six hours on low.  It was a hit!!!

This is a FIVE star recipe. But since I changed the wine to chicken broth It wouldnt be fair for me to give it a 5 after changing one of the ingredients. And I definately made the right choice!!!  When I first made the sauce it was a little to salty (probably from the broth) but after cooking for a few hours the chicken juices  thinned it out just enough to balance the salt.  Is a keeper for sure!!!

text:
Family LOVED it.  I expected it to need more spice, but it was pretty good as is.  I used both wine (1/2 cup) and chicken broth (1/2 cup).  Browned the chicken on the stove first with butter & S&P.  Added fresh mushrooms while chicken was browning.  Placed chicken in pan, then covered with heated soup mixture and cooked in oven for a few minutes.  Added extra pepper to the soup mix.  When done, added pasta & mixed.  Will try adding some broccoli next time.  A keeper!

Yum!!  In the interest of time, I browned the chicken in just 2 T. of butter.  Then I removed the chicken from the pan and added remaining ingredients, plus 1/2 C. of hot water (the sauce seemed too thick to me).  Returned  the chicken to the pan and simmered, covered, about 20 minutes while I cooked the pasta.  Will be making this again!

text:
More like 4 1/2 stars! This was a delicious dish!!! I pretty much followed the recipe, but doubled the sauce (but left the italian dressing mix at 1 and 1/4) and added about 1/2 cup of milk so it wasn't extremely thick. I sauteed some fresh baby portabella mushrooms and steamed some broccoli and it put it on top of the chicken in the backing dish. (The broccoli was a GREAT touch..)  I didn't have chive cream cheese, so I made my own. I heated my soups, wine, cream cheese and milk concoction and then added it to the 'shroom, broccoli, chicken mix.  I cooked everything at 350 for 45 minutes and it came out perfect!  It was a little soupy, but I'd rather have too much sauce then not enough!!  I served it over bowtie pasta.  Fiance LOVED it.. will be making again very soon!

Like many others here, I doubled the amount of sauce, but I kept the same amount of chicken and pasta.  I added 8 oz of sliced mushrooms, and a diced red bell pepper.    I also cooked mine in a saucepan on the stove.  I keep a carton of milk nearby, because as the sauce simmers, it gets really thick, so I add a splash of milk every few minutes to keep it thinned down.  (1/2-1 cup total maybe.)  That really helps with the saltiness.

text:
This was good but very rich.  I doubled the sauce using one can of golden mushroom soup and one can of cream of mushroom chicken soup.  To the sauce I added chives since my cream cheese was plain.  I placed the chicken on the bottom of the pan and topped with sliced mushrooms.  Then I poured the sauce over the top and baked.  When it was done, I served it over bow-tie pasta.  Also to speed up the melting time of the cream cheese, I warmed it slightly in my microwave on the melt butter setting.

text:
I followed the advice of other reviewer's and doubled the sauce.  I also used the recommended 1/2 C wine and 1/2 C chicken broth, plus almost all of the 8oz chive cream cheese.  It was a hit.  I grilled the chicken to about 3/4 done on our indoor grill after seasoning and then sliced it and added it into the sauce on the stovetop where it simmered covered for the 10 or so minutes it took to cook the pasta.  Very good flavor and quite easy.  Will make again.

text:
A bit rich, but VERY yummy! I made just a few additions by adding a can of diced tomatoes and a few shakes of Tabasco (just personal preference).  Calculated the recipe for a serving of 8, although I only made it with 6 breasts and cubed the chicken.  Wanted to be sure I had enough sauce based on some other reviews saying not enough. Covered for 1/2 the cooking time then uncovered for second 1/2. And used Penne Rigata pasta.  When I eat the leftovers, I may try it with brown rice...this seems like a dish you can eat with either.  Definitely a keeper!

None
text:
I made this tonite with a few changes...cut up 2 lbs of  breast tenderloins and sauteed in olive oil, after seasoning with seasoned salt. Made the sauce separately with chicken broth instead of white wine, and cream of chicken soup instead of golden mushroom (this was all I had on hand). Added the sauce to the chicken and simmered for 30 mins, then put over bow tie pasta and added peas. I asked my husband for the rating and he gave it 4 stars....but my picky 4 year old loved it, and it is going into my box to keep. Thanks for posting this great recipe!

I have to admit, when I saw the ingredients for this recipe I was very skeptical.  However, I took a chance because of the great reviews and I was pleasantly surprised!  This has to be the best chicken/pasta dish I have ever had. Definitely something you can make for company because it looks elegant and also tastes like something you would get at a nice restaurant. I have made this about a dozen times now, usually served with cubed new potatoes baked with a bit of Italian dressing from a bottle.  Try it, you'll like it!

text:
This was a great meal. We did tweak the recipe a little bit. We substituted water for the white wine and added 1/4 cup Spanish black olives to the sauce. Next time I think we will add fresh mushrooms. We didn't have any on hand otherwise would have tried that addition as well. We cut the chicken into thin strips, seasoned and cooked them in a skillet, then baked with the sauce for 30 minutes instead of the 60 given. This will be a recipe we continue to use for many years. It is so easy and we usually have all of the ingredients on hand, even in Asia! Gave it 4 stars because we have had dishes we prefer better, but this is still an excellent and filling meal!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mediocre at best. My bf liked this (which is surprising because he doesn't care for cream cheese, cream soups or mushrooms), but he is willing to try anything at least once. I don't like mushrooms either, but can tolerate cream of mushroom soup (go figure!). Taking the advice of another reviewer, I looked for cream of chicken with herbs soup at my local supermarket, but they were all out (bummer!). I ended up subbing cream of chicken with mushroom soup instead. For the cream cheese, I purchased an 8 oz. tub of spreadable chive & onion cream cheese (which worked fine - I "scooped" out a quarter of it for the sauce since I made half the recipe). Thought this had a very distinctive winey taste (which I didn't care for) and my sauce was quite "watery" right out of the oven. Served over my grocer's generic brand creamy herb noodles with French-style green beans and garlic bread on the side. Certainly not "bad", but not WOW and definitely not worthy of making it on my regular menu rotation. Thanks for sharing though!

This was excellent tasting & so easy to prepare. My husband loved it and claimed it was the best pasta he'd ever had. I've read a few reviews- and I have to say do NOT leave out the wine! It gives it such a rich kick! It's essential to the wow factor of this pasta dish.

I altered this a little, to use what I had on hand. I used regular cream of mushroom soup, and regular cream cheese with a litle "Onion Onion" seasoning by Tastefully Simple thrown in, everything else I followed for the sauce. I also used wheat spaghetti instead of angel hair pasta. It was SO yummy!! We really liked the way the flavor of the wheat pasta blended with the flavors in the sauce - perfectly creamy and great taste! I cut the chicken in the 9x13 pan and then tossed it all (with the pasta and sauce) before serving. Next time I will add mushrooms and probably some steamed broccoli.

Delicious.  I cooked this for my family and when they ask for seconds--that means it is really good.  However 4 stars because made as written, i thought it a bit salty.  I would agree to double the sauce or use only half of the dry dressing mix.  I only used a generous dollop of chive cream cheese and that was plenty. Incidentally, i didn't realize until i was ready to cook that it took 60 minutes in the oven; i just heated i through and served over the pasta.  Will definitely make again.  Thanks for a great recipe; the sauce seems very versatile !!

text:
Wow!  This was SO easy and SO delicious.  Even my picky 5 yr old daughter loved it.  IMPORTANT - be sure you get the Campbells Golden Mushroom Condensed Soup - NOT cream of mushroom.  I think some of the 'bad' reviews saying it was bland must have used the wrong soup - there was NOTHING bland about this dish.  I made a small modification with the wine.  I only used a 1/4 cup of while wine and 1/2 cup chicken broth.  Also, I used regular cream cheese and added my own dried chives.  Enjoy!   Its a a definite keeper.

text:
We too love this recipe. We have made it many times! I originally chose it to make a special dinner for my husband, who in turn loved it. The only thing he was concerned with, once I told him the ingredients, was the cooking wine. So, we searched online, and i discovered alternatives to the wine. We chose to use sparkling white grape juice instead. Another option that we considered was gingerale. The sparkling white grape juice worked just as well as the white wine! There was a slightly different taste, but my husband loved the sparkling white grape juice more!  Also, another thing that we have tried... at times, we have only had regular cream of mushroom soup. We just add 2 beef bullion cubes to the mixture once we stir in the soup. This is an excellent recipe worth having and sharing over and over! Thanks so much!

text:
4 as written. 5 with the following changes:

- doubled sauce (except italian seasoning packet)
- used chicken broth instead of wine
- added 1/4 teaspoon cayenne powder to sauce
- added 2 tablespoons of sugar to sauce
- used egg noodles (or rice) instead of angel hair
- add mushrooms to sauce when cooking
- add cooked broccoli to sauce at end

My boyfriend and I ate it all up.

text:
I made this in the crockpot - it smelled great and I will make it this way next time.  But this is what I will do differently:  Not cut up the chicken/use whole breasts, add some additional seasoning (garlic, parsley, etc) and use a different pasta.  I used fresh angelhair and it kind of turned to mush.  Next time I'd use dry rotini or bowtie pasta.  Also, I'd add fresh broccoli to the crockpot the last 10 or 15 minutes.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pantry was a bit bare today, but I found that I had most of the ingredients for this recipe.  Wanting to make this a bit more healthy I substitued with reduced fat cream cheese, 2/3 can 98% fat free Cream of Celery, only used 2 Tbls butter, used beer (Coors light) instead of wine (the Hubs hates the taste of white wine in sauces), and served over fiber enriched penne pasta.  I cut my three giant chicken breast into wide 2 inch stripes to decrease the cooking time.  
I must admit that I was skeptical, but the outcome was a very tasty dish. 

Next time (after I've gone shopping), I'll add some fresh mushrooms, maybe peas or brocolli.  AND I really think the addition of beer (however a cheap one) provided a nice ballance to tone down the tanginess of the sauce.  I imagine a white wine could contribute to a tangy sauce in a way that we may not like.
Review:

text:
This dish is DELISH! I altered a little and here is what I did. I pan seared the chicken breast with salt and pepper until browned slightly and put in slow-cooker. I did the sauce with low sodium cream of chicken soup and the rest as directed. I added the mixture to the slow-cooker and let it simmer all day. I removed the chicken to set aside and put mixture in a saucepan and added some whipping cream and a little sherry to make it real "saucy" and then added it to chicken on top of whole wheat angel hair and WOW! Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
My husband and I liked this recipe and I will add it to my recipe box.  I doubled the sauce because a lot of reviewers said to do this and I like a lot of sauce, but I had enough left over to feed an army.  Instead of wine I used reduced sodium, fat free chicken broth.  I used one can chicken soup, and one can mushroom, as well and chive and onion cream cheese.  I didn't think it was too salty, but it's probably not that easy on your waste line. Next time I'm going to try it with fat free or reduced fat cream cheese and maybe add fresh chives, mushrooms, garlic, and onions, for a fresher taste. It tasted great with broccoli and rolls though.  Thanks for a great recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe several times and it's definitely one of my favorites on this site. It's quite easy to prepare! 
You can change the soup to cream of chicken, brocoli, celery, etc. 
Wine can be substituted with chicken broth.
I usually use margarine instead of butter, 1 package of Italian salad dressing, 1 cup of white wine, 2 cans of soup and 1 package of onion and chives cream cheese. Depending on the texture I want, I add chicken broth. 
I often prepare the sauce and put it on top of the chicken in a crock pot, on low for 5-6 hours. Turns out great every time! If you leave it longer, the chicken falls apart, which is great served over pasta.
Review:

text:
Really good but really salty!  I cut down on the salt by adding more cream cheese and thinning the sauce with low sodium chicken broth (I like thinner sauce with angel hair anyway).

My daughter is a vegetarian, so I baked some of the sauce over some tofu slices.  (Her sauce was thinned with water, not broth, I couldn't tell the difference.)

Great with broccoli on the side!

The only reason I did not give it 5 stars is because it is so rich that I wouldn't want to make it regularly.

Display Name:
ADRIANE2

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading several pages of reviews, I kind of winged it and mine turned out great!  I cut up the chicken and slightly browned it in a little bit of olive oil and soy sauce for flavor. In the saucepan, I used almost a full stick of butter, 1 pkg Good Seasons Italian drsg mix, 1.5 cans of golden mushroom soup, 1/2 cup white cooking wine, 1/2 cup chicken broth, and about 6-7 oz of cream cheese with chives and onions (all I could find). I added a little bit of milk  because it did taste a bit salty to me before the milk.  I just kept stirring it all together on med. heat until it was smooth.  I poured it over the chicken in 9 x13 baking dish and cooked about 45 minutes.  My husband and I loved it on the angel hair pasta!!  Great flavor, not too salty.  I will definately make this again!!!

country:
None
text:
Excellent!  I did make a few changes:  cut up chicken breasts and browned in olive oil, omitted salad dressing mix and used Italian seasoning instead, used regular cream cheese and substituted chicken broth for the white wine.  I also sauteed some onions, peppers and mushrooms to add to the sauce.  I then mixed all the ingredients for the sauce together in a bowl (I softened the cream cheese in the microwave) and put everything together in the crockpot and cooked on low about 6 hours.  I used rigatoni instead of angel hair.  Delicious.  I recommend using the soup called for in the recipe - completely different than cream of mushroom soup.  Thanks.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was pretty good.  I'm a beginner cook, and added a whole stick of butter which is double the amount it's supposed to have (OOPS!!) so I ended up having to put in more wine, a can of cream of mushroom soup in addition to the golden mushroom soup, and 8 oz. of the cream cheese with chives.  So essentially I doubled the sauce, which was needed.  I couldn't imagine making this dish without doubling the amount of sauce.  I used linguine noodles.  I sauteed the chicken that I cut up in pieces (in a frying pan on stovetop) in olive oil to brown them.  I added chopped fresh garlic to the butter before adding the rest of the ingredients for the sauce.  Overall this turned out pretty tasty even with my goof with too much butter (I spooned most of it out when it settled on the top.)  I don't know if I'll ever be a great cook but this website really helps me out.  Thanks for the recipe Marian!

text:
This was great.  I went to three stores and could not find cream cheese w/chives.  They use to sell it, so don't know what is going on.  I bought green onions diced up the greens and mixed with the cream cheese.  I use wine if on hand if not extra broth.  If your sauce is to thin in a bowl mix a litte water and corn starch.  Whisk together then add to pan.  It will thicken it up. We don't like angel haired pasta so we use linguine or whatever.  It's a personal preference.  Thanks for the post.  This is great.

Display Name:
Kristy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe has real potential! Boyfriend found the unchanged recipe sauce too thick, I found it too salty. I made the sauce as is, then poured 3/4ths of it over the chicken baking in the oven (which doesn't dry out if you only cook it for 30 minutes or so at 400 degrees). I thinned out the remaining sauce with half a soup can of water and about 1/4th cup milk, and tossed that with the pasta before adding the chicken. After trying fettucine pasta, I tried making this with bow-tie pasta; I think the sauce sticks to bow-tie better. It gets better as leftovers.:) Next time, in addition to adding roasted red peppers and maybe artichokes, I'll try the trick recommended by an earlier reviewer of cubing a raw potato into the sauce while it's simmering to soak up the salt. I guess you just spoon the potato out after it cooks in the sauce. What an intriguing idea! Thanks for the recipe, Marian!

text:
I can't stop making this dish!  The sauce is such a tasty alternative to a tomato sauce.  There's really no tweaking necessary for the ingredients, but I'm playing with the quantities.  Tonight I'm doubling the sauce because last time I tried tossing it with the pasta instead of serving it on top (to keep the pasta moister for the leftovers) and a lot of the flavor was lost.  I also tried cutting the chicken into cubes to facilitate the tossing, but I don't think I'll do that again.  I'm going to have some of the leftover sauce with rice for lunch!

I saw this recipe months ago but wasn't sure it was something we'd like. Golden mushroom soup, Italian seasonings and white wine didn't really sound like a good combination to me.  But when I came across it again and saw how many good reviews it had, I decided to give it a try.  I'm so happy I did!  Not only is the dish delicious, it's also very easy.  I love that you just pour the sauce over the chicken and pop it in the oven.  The sauce is amazing and the chicken was so tender.  I did follow other suggestions and doubled the sauce so that we could keep eating it with noodles once the chicken is gone.  Thank you for a great recipe!  I'll be passing this one along to friends!

Wow!! This dish is way too good, my family loved it. I did alter the recipe a little after listening to other reviewers. I added double the sour cream and double the mushroom soup, also added some mushroom. I kept the wine instead of using chicken broth as others have suggested and actually added in a bit more wine just because my family loves wine in food. But yeah I'm definately making this again, DELICIOUS!

I didn't read the reviews as I normally do before making this and I should have, I figured with over 800 reviews and 5 stars I was safe. Totally agree it was WAY too salty and "packaged" tasting. If I made it again, I would use unsalted butter and less of the seasoning packet. I also would add some more mushrooms. My hubby liked it and said he'd eat the rest for lunch tomorrow 'cause I certainly didn't want it. I probably won't make it again.

text:
I gave this four stars because my roommate raved about it and he doesn't even like salty food.  I agreed with many reviewers it was very salty and the sauce was far too thick and gummy, but the flavor was great.  Is it possible that the submitter left out the step of adding the can of water with the soup?  I saw that some reviewers claimed the sauce was runny--I don't see how that's possible without having added the additional can of water.  I will definitely try the recipe again with maybe 1/2 a can of water or some low sodium chicken broth.  Definitely deserves a second try!!!

I really, really wanted to love this recipe, but unfortunately did not.  It was edible, but as other reviewers said too salty and processed tasting. I did reduce the Italian packet to per suggestion. It really depends on your taste buds, I think.  You will either love this recipe and want it for every meal or not like it very much at all.
